channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: October 8
item.description: A man performing a fire stunt in Amritsar, Punjab.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A Sikh man performing a fire stunt in Amritsar, Punjab, on the eve of the anniversary of the birth of Guru Ram Das, the fourth of the ten gurus of Sikhs.

item.title: Obama Expected to Reduce Military Aid to Egypt
item.description: The anticipated move will hold up weapons delivery, but not counterterrorism aid, in the wake of a deadly military crackdown on the Muslim Brotherhood.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Rights Advocates Suing U.N. Over the Spread of Cholera in Haiti
item.description: Advocates for Haitian victims of a cholera epidemic that afflicted the country three years ago are suing the United Nations, saying its peacekeepers introduced the disease through sewage contamination.
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: At War Blog: The Day My War Ended
item.description: An Army officer recalls what he saw and felt on duty in Baghdad on Oct. 7, 2003, a day he says signaled a tipping point in the war in Iraq.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DON GOMEZ
item.media:description: American soldiers outside the Bayaa mosque in Baghdad on Oct. 7, 2003.

item.title: Lawyer Sought for Terror Suspect Held on Navy Ship
item.description: The chief federal public defender in Manhattan asked that his office be appointed to represent the suspect, Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai, who had been captured in Libya.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Britain and Iran Move to Repair Diplomatic Relations
item.description: Britain and Iran announced they would each appoint a chargé d’affaires, a step below ambassador, to work toward resuming full diplomatic ties, including reopening embassies.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: World Briefing | the Americas: Mexico: 13 Federal Officers Are Arrested on Murder and Kidnapping Charges
item.description: The authorities accused the suspects of belonging to a kidnapping and murder gang in the Pacific coast resort of Acapulco.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Garment Shop Fire Kills 10
item.description: Ten bodies were found inside the Aswad garment factory in Gazipur, and several people were injured trying to escape from the building, a fire official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Higgs and Englert Are Awarded Nobel Prize in Physics
item.description: François Englert of Belgium and Peter W. Higgs of Britain were honored for suggesting that an invisible ocean of energy is responsible for the mass and diversity of the universe.
item.dc:creator: By DENNIS OVERBYE
item.media:description: Scientists at CERN in Switzerland reacted Tuesday to the announcement of the winners of the Nobel Prize in Physics.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Decision in Bo Xilai Appeal Expected Soon
item.description: Bo Xilai, a former senior Communist Party official who was sentenced to life in prison last month, expects a court in eastern China to make a decision soon on his appeal, a family associate said.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: ‘Imperfect Intelligence’ Said to Hinder U.S. Raid on Militant in Somalia
item.description: The Navy SEALs who approached the Somali coast in pursuit of a militant seen as a pivotal connection for extremists encountered more civilians than they expected, American officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Police Fire on Tibetan Protesters, Report Says
item.description: A Tibet advocacy group and Radio Free Asia said Chinese security forces had fired on a protest in an eastern town in the Tibet Autonomous Region, injuring at least 60 people.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: European Lawmakers Reject Tight Restrictions on E-Cigarettes
item.description: The European Parliament, in a move favored by users and producers of electronic cigarettes, voted against regulating the products as medical devices.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and MATT RICHTEL

item.title: Argentine President Undergoes Surgery for Blood Clot
item.description: The procedure to drain a blood clot near President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner’s brain went “very well,” her spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: The Lede: Iran’s Foreign Minister Discusses Twitter, Netanyahu and Kerry on State Television
item.description: While restrictions on the use of social networks by Iranians remain in place, Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif spoke openly on state television about his love of Twitter banter.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Envoys Near Deal to Free Ex-Premier of Ukraine
item.description: Under the agreement, Yulia V. Tymoshenko would be pardoned by her rival, President Viktor F. Yanukovich, in exchange for a commitment from her to leave the country.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: India Increases Effort to Harness Biomass Energy
item.description: The prime minister of India has called for a doubling of the alternative energy supply by 2017, and some see a big opportunity in using the country’s abundance of agricultural waste as fuel.
item.dc:creator: By AMY YEE
item.media:credit: Manpreet Romana for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers collect rice straw from the fields in Baghoura, a village in northern India.

item.title: European Union Official Calls for More Surveillance of Migrant Routes
item.description: A European Union commissioner said more patrols would help prevent disasters like the sinking of a boat near Sicily last week that killed hundreds of African migrants.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:description: Italian police officers photographed migrants in Sicily on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,269 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Second Team of Weapons Experts to Head to Syria
item.description: The new team will expand on the work undertaken by an initial team from the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: United Nations vehicles leaving a hotel in Damascus last week.

item.title: India Ink: An Indian’s Maiden Visit to Pakistan
item.description: Ultimately, cross-border movement for trade and commerce, for tourism and travel, and for health care and education, will go far in ameliorating the longstanding distrust between India and Pakistan, author argues.
item.dc:creator: By SATCHIT BALSARI
item.media:description: Manmohan Singh, prime minister of India, right, with his Pakistani counterpart Nawaz Sharif during the United Nations General Assembly in New York on Sept. 29.

item.title: Daqaqa Journal: Mourning Syrian Soldier, but Not Doubting a War
item.description: The civil war has exacted a brutal toll, yet at a funeral for a soldier from a coastal town, grief was tempered with loyalty for the government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral of Abu Layth, a 24-year-old lieutenant in the Syrian army, in the hamlet of Daqaqa in Syria’s coastal foothills.

item.title: The Female Factor: Li Tianyi Sentencing Is Small Step for Chinese Women
item.description: When the Haidian District Court in Beijing sentenced five men to prison for gang rape, the ruling went against widespread attitude.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Former Swiss Bank Employee Advising Spanish Political Party in Tax Battle
item.description: Hervé Falciani, who revealed secret account information about tax evaders, is assuming a new role as an anticorruption adviser to a newly formed political party in Spain.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL

item.title: European Officials Consulted Business Leaders on Trade Pact
item.description: Internal documents obtained by The New York Times show the business community was seeking an active role in writing new regulations.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
